Roma Komarov

How Should <selectedoption> Work? â€” A new HTML element! Weâ€™re getting a way to style and customize <select> elements in certain situations, via <selectedoption>. But there are concerns on sync and state issues, and Jake seeks feedback on the practicalities of the intendedÂ behavior.

Jake Archibald

Build a Daily Workout Tracker with Clerk, Convex, and Expo â€” "Daily Reps" is a workout tracker app to set daily goals & track progress, resetting daily. Built with React Native & Expo, it uses Clerk for user management & Convex for real-time data, offering a powerful cross-platform fitness trackingÂ solution.

Clerk sponsor

ğŸ“Š Â The State of CSS 2024 Survey Results â€” Sacha Greif notes how 2024 may go down as something of a turning point between classic CSS and â€˜new CSSâ€™ â€” what with the many new features and tooling introduced in recent years now reaching a level of widespread browser support, and more importantly, usage. Lots of interesting data points to dig into here (shoutout to the 34 people who said they test their sites on aÂ smartwatch).

Devographics

So, Your CMS Blew Up. Any Decent WordPress Alternatives OutÂ There? â€” No matter which side of the debate you find yourself, I think itâ€™s fair to say the mess with WordPress has been universally frustrating in some way or another. As such, Ernie â€” in his typical engaging style â€” outlines some CMS alternatives that you may at least have on your radar if things go furtherÂ south.

Ernie Smith

  • ğŸ‰ Svelte 5, the latest release of the popular, compiled frontend UI framework, has beenÂ released.

WebKit

Where Web Components Shine â€” Dave shares a quick-fire list of the specific pros and cons of using web components today â€” highlighting strengths, such as low memory usage, style encapsulation, and quick prototyping â€” along with pointing out challenges, including accessibilityÂ concerns.

Dave Rupert

StackBlitz sponsor

Ahmad Alfy

Victor Ayomipo

How Microsoft Edge is Replacing React with Web Components â€” As part of their WebUI 2.0 project, the Edge browser team is on a mission to swap out React UI components with native web platform components, largely for performanceÂ reasons.

Richard MacManus (The New Stack)

Hyper-Responsive Web Components â€” Dives into the nuance of getting an embeddable call-to-action sign up component working in as many places as possible (any position, and viewport, any amount ofÂ content).

Trys Mudford

Kevin Powell

Practical Accessibility Tips You Can Apply Today
Kevin Andrews

Khoshnus: A Library to 'Bring Life' to SVG Text â€” A library for â€˜bringing life to static text in an artistic way.â€™ Essentially it takes SVG text and animates it into existence on yourÂ page.

Amer Jabar

CSS Spring Easing Generator: Make Generating Spring Easings More Intuitive â€” The tool allows you to customize two main settings: perceptual duration (in milliseconds) and bounce (%). You an also select from three presets and the code is generated as CSS variables for use with CSSÂ animations.

Kevin Grajeda

AuthKit: The Worldâ€™s Best Login Box â€” Powered by WorkOS &Â Radix â€” AuthKit is a complete solution for authentication, authorization, and user management. Itâ€™s free up to 1 million MAUs and comes standard with RBAC, bot protection, MFA, andÂ more.

AuthKit sponsor

HEXÂ·P3: Quickly Convert HEX Colors to the Display P3 ColorÂ Space â€” The resulting code uses the relatively new CSS color() function with the display-p3, which according to the spec, â€˜enables more vibrant greens and reds than the sRGB colorÂ gamutâ€™.

Wojtek Witkowski

Emoji-Fallback.js: Provide Support for Emojis on All Browsers â€” Replaces emoji characters with emoji images on devices that don't have emojiÂ support.

Jared Van Valkengoed

elva: A Multilingual, Clean, Starter Theme for Eleventy â€” Eleventy / 11ty is a popular Node.js-powered static site generator â€“ Demo here.
Scott Evans

The Proposed Interop 2025 Focus Areas â€” A few weeks back we mentioned how ideas and proposals were being sought for Interop 2025. You can now look over all of the ideas put forward, share your feedback, and upvote those you like the lookÂ of. Here's how the full proposal selection processÂ works, with the chosen priorities announced nextÂ February.

web platform tests

HTML for People â€” An approachable, friendly set of teachings around creating HTML pages, going from the basics, to adding style, getting things online, and exploring reusable components too. Itâ€™s a well presented, understandable starter guide of sorts â€” a good one to share with anyÂ beginner.

Blake Watson beginner

Announcing Gitpod Flex â€” Gitpod Flex automates your full dev environmentâ€”yes, including tools and secrets. Speed up work, boost productivity, and collaborate securely with zero-trust security whether coding locally, in the cloud, orÂ on-prem.

Gitpod Flex sponsor

'Iâ€™ve Been Doing Blockquotes Wrong' â€” If you skipped past HTML for People above because youâ€™re an HTML expert, Michelleâ€™s moment of reflection around the blockquote element might make you pause for thought. HTML is hard, she notes, not least because itâ€™s both easy and relatively safe to write bad HTML (unlike with badÂ JavaScript).

Michelle Barker

An Abridged History of Safari Showstoppers â€” The â€˜receiptsâ€™ to prove that Safari on iOS is â€œan inconvenience for developersâ€ and â€œthe fundamental reason interoperability has been stymied in mobileÂ ecosystemsâ€. Uh-oh, we're getting flashbacks to the IE6Â days..

CSS Nesting Improves with CSSNestedDeclarations â€” CSSNestedDeclarations is a new, CSS Working Group approved interface to fix some quirks of CSS nesting, such as declarations that come after style rules confusingly shifting up. Itâ€™s in Chrome from v130, and testing is underway in Firefox and Safari. Bramus shares a quick behind-the-scenesÂ here but in short: "This means that CSS nesting got a whole lot better as of Chrome 130."

Bramus Van Damme (Google)

Uh-oh, .io?Â The Disappearance of an Internet Domain? â€” The British government recently announced it was transferring sovereignty of the Chagos Islands to Mauritius. But how can geopolitics alter digital infrastructure? The decision may result in the loss of one of the tech and gaming industryâ€™s much-loved (though problematic) top-level domains: .io.

Gareth Edwards

The First Newsletter Dedicated to ProductÂ Engineers â€” The fastest growing startups increasingly rely on product engineers. These are engineers with the skills to figure out what to build. Product for Engineers is dedicated to sharing the skills and strategies needed to succeed in thisÂ role.

PostHog sponsor

"Automattic is Doing Open Source Dirty" â€” DHH (of Ruby on Rails fame) chimes in on the ongoing WordPress saga, which seems to show no sign of abating soon. He states a concern â€œabout the integrity of open source licensesâ€, adding that such â€œintegrity is under direct assault by Automatticâ€™s grotesque claim for WP Engineâ€™sÂ revenuesâ€. Matt Mullenweg of WordPress replied on X.

David Heinemeier Hansson

Searching for a New CSS Logo â€” Did you know that there's an active, ongoing search for a logo to help visualize all things CSS and â€œaid in the marketing and promotion of the new CSS eraâ€? Thereâ€™s a bunch of discussion and suggested designs being shared in the CSS-NextÂ repo.

Ryan Trimble

Firefox 131 'Supercharges' CSS Variables Debugging â€” Version 131 of Mozillaâ€™s browser was released last week adding notable improvements to debugging CSS variables along with other InspectorÂ improvements.

Nicolas Chevobbe

Debugging a Slack Integration with Sentryâ€™s Trace View â€” Read how our engineers used Sentry on Sentry to fix a Slack integration issue, improving the overall userÂ experience.

Sentry sponsor

â–¶Â Â State Queries â€” Una and Adam discuss a future web capability that builds on container queries: state queries. This upcoming feature will, for example, be able to detect if a container is overflowing, when an element is scroll snapped, and when an element is stuck from position: sticky.

Chrome for Developers

Plain Vanilla: A Tutorial Website for Plain Vanilla Web Development â€” The incentive behind this project is to teach building complex and dynamic apps without complex tools â€“ just HTML, CSS, and JS, using modern features like Web Components, hash-based routing, etc.

Joeri Sebrechts

â–¶Â Â Web Components: Little Bits â€” In this ~20 minute video from the recent State of the Browser conference, David shares how he is using Web Components to help develop complex design systems as well as custom open-sourceÂ tools. More videos from the event are available too.

David Darnes

Building a Robust Frontend with Progressive Enhancement â€” The UK government website is a rare and successful example of running a huge, behemoth of a site, with strong, robust systems and sound user experience considerations. Here, they touch upon how progressive enhancement plays a crucial role in making thingsÂ tick.

player.style: Video & Audio Player Themes for Every Web Player &Â Framework â€” A collection of well-presented, good looking web component media players (...and one that looks like how you remember WinAmp). Lots of customization options and easy copy and paste resultsÂ too.

Mux

PlaceholderJS: Ridiculously Simple and Lightweight Placeholders â€” Available for use via a CDN or as a React component, these are simple SVG-based placeholders that you can customize (size, color, background, etc.) using URL or componentÂ parameters.

Owen Bick

Securing Node.js Express APIs with Clerk and React â€” Secure Express API endpoints and integrate authentication without the complexity of building it fromÂ scratch.

Clerk sponsor

Statichunt: A Directory of 3900+ Composable Themes, Templates & Tools for Static Site Generators â€” An organized collection of tools that you can filter using categories like Astro, Hugo, Gatsby, Eleventy, Jekyll, etc., as well as framework keywords like Tailwind, Bootstrap, Bulma, etc.

ZEON STUDIO

qrframe: A Library to Generate 'Pretty' QRÂ Codes â€” An odd project as the QR codes generated arenâ€™t always guaranteed to scan reliably, but if you can generate one that does, they're very striking. Could be useful for branding/fun use cases. You can play around with a live demoÂ here.

Kyle Zheng
